<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 293]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 298, 379, 314]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 A Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 278, 905, 293]]<|/det|>
9702/43  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 299, 905, 314]]<|/det|>
May/June 2019  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[840, 320, 905, 335]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 339, 415, 355]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 366, 375]]<|/det|>
No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 386, 408]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 715, 432]]<|/det|>
Write your centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 432, 325, 447]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 447, 504, 462]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 462, 504, 477]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 476, 380, 491]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 502, 255, 517]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 359, 543]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 543, 767, 558]]<|/det|>
You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 568, 604, 583]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 583, 759, 598]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 73, 126, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 102, 670, 560]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81\mathrm{m s}^{- 2}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 107, 561, 144]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 163, 526, 180]]<|/det|>
\[W = \rho \Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 195, 537, 225]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{Gm}{r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 235, 522, 252]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \rho gh\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 262, 561, 294]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V}\langle c^2\rangle\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 305, 536, 322]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\omega^2 x\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 339, 608, 375]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_{0}\cos \omega t\] \[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{(\chi_{0}^{2} - \chi^{2})}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 380, 536, 415]]<|/det|>
\[f_{0} = \frac{f_{s}V}{\nu \pm \nu_{s}}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 425, 537, 459]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 467, 628, 486]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_{1} + 1 / C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 500, 596, 518]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_{1} + C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 528, 526, 555]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 570, 532, 587]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 603, 596, 621]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 636, 628, 655]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_{1} + 1 / R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 668, 518, 700]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{H}} = \frac{BI}{ntq}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 714, 558, 732]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 747, 578, 766]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 775, 536, 810]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[295, 72, 700, 88]]<|/det|>
Answer **all** the questions in the spaces provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 102, 99, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 148, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 771, 120]]<|/det|>
Two point masses are isolated in space and are separated by a distance x.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 920, 166]]<|/det|>
State an expression relating the gravitational force \(F\) between the two masses to the magnitudes \(M\) and \(m\) of the masses. State the name of any other symbol used.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 273, 144, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 273, 720, 291]]<|/det|>
A spacecraft is to be put into a circular orbit about a spherical planet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 304, 920, 336]]<|/det|>
The planet may be considered to be isolated in space. The mass of the planet, assumed to be concentrated at its centre, is \(7.5 \times 10^{23} \text{kg}\). The radius of the planet is \(3.4 \times 10^{6} \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 351, 181, 369]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 351, 920, 383]]<|/det|>
The spacecraft is to orbit the planet at a height of \(2.4 \times 10^{5} \text{m}\) above the surface of the planet. At this altitude, there is no atmosphere.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 396, 745, 414]]<|/det|>
Show that the speed of the spacecraft in its orbit is \(3.7 \times 10^{3} \text{m s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 615, 920, 632]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 887, 89]]<|/det|>
One possible path of the spacecraft as it approaches the planet is shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 102, 843, 275]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 297, 589, 316]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 329, 755, 348]]<|/det|>
The spacecraft enters the orbit at point A with speed \(3.7 \times 10^{3} \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 361, 920, 394]]<|/det|>
At point B, a distance of \(5.00 \times 10^{7} \text{m}\) from the centre of the planet, the spacecraft has a speed of \(4.1 \times 10^{3} \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\). The mass of the spacecraft is \(650 \text{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 407, 920, 440]]<|/det|>
For the spacecraft moving from point B to point A, show that the change in gravitational potential energy of the spacecraft is \(8.3 \times 10^{9} \text{J}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 674, 920, 692]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 705, 144, 723]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 705, 920, 753]]<|/det|>
By considering changes in gravitational potential energy and in kinetic energy of the spacecraft, determine whether the total energy of the spacecraft increases or decreases in moving from point B to point A. A numerical answer is not required.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 861, 920, 880]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 892, 920, 909]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
A fixed mass of an ideal gas has volume \(210 \text{cm}^3\) at pressure \(3.0 \times 10^5 \text{Pa}\) and temperature \(270 \text{K}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 841, 123]]<|/det|>
The volume of the gas is reduced at constant pressure to \(140 \text{cm}^3\), as shown in Fig. 2.1.

Determine:

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 904, 920, 923]]<|/det|>
<form>work done = .................................................... J [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 918, 89]]<|/det|>
For this change in volume and temperature of the gas, the thermal energy transferred is 53 J.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 616, 120]]<|/det|>
Determine \(\Delta U,\) the change in internal energy of the gas.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[539, 286, 920, 304]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\Delta U = ............................................................\) J [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 318, 920, 336]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 720, 91]]<|/det|>
A hollow tube, sealed at one end, has a cross-sectional area \(A\) of \(24 \text{cm}^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 87, 777, 106]]<|/det|>
The tube contains sand so that the total mass \(M\) of the tube and sand is \(0.23 \text{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 697, 136]]<|/det|>
The tube floats upright in a liquid of density \(\rho\), as illustrated in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 147, 789, 361]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 367, 532, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 397, 648, 416]]<|/det|>
The depth of the bottom of the tube below the liquid surface is \(h\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 426, 918, 460]]<|/det|>
The tube is displaced vertically and then released. The variation with time \(t\) of the depth \(h\) is shown in Fig. 3.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 472, 875, 781]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 789, 534, 808]]<|/det|>

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 819, 252, 837]]<|/det|>
Determine:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 844, 183, 863]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 843, 549, 861]]<|/det|>

<form>amplitude = .................................................... $m$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[917, 927, 920, 945]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[482, 255, 920, 274]]<|/det|>

the acceleration of the tube when \(h\) is a maximum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 470, 920, 489]]<|/det|>
<form>acceleration = .................................................... $m s^{-2}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[912, 470, 922, 489]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 502, 146, 521]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 501, 712, 521]]<|/det|>
The frequency \(f\) of oscillation of the tube is given by the expression

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 523, 564, 559]]<|/det|>
\[f = \frac{1}{2\pi}\sqrt{(\frac{A\rho g}{M})}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 562, 472, 581]]<|/det|>
where \(g\) is the acceleration of free fall.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 593, 680, 612]]<|/det|>
Calculate the density \(\rho\) of the liquid in which the tube is floating.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 778, 922, 797]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\rho =\) ............................................ $kg m^{-3}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 809, 920, 845]]<|/det|>
The oscillations illustrated in Fig. 3.2 are undamped. In practice, the liquid does cause light damping.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 856, 920, 875]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 3.2, draw a line to show light damping of the oscillations for time \(t = 0\) to time \(t = 1.4 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 799, 91]]<|/det|>
During the transmission of a signal, attenuation occurs and noise is picked up.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 354, 121]]<|/det|>
State what is meant by:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 183, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 134, 292, 152]]<|/det|>
attenuation

<mark>[1]

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 351, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
By reference to (a)(ii), explain the advantage of the transmission of the signal in digital form rather than in analogue form.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 428, 920, 445]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 459, 146, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 459, 544, 477]]<|/det|>
Part of an analogue signal is shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 492, 878, 875]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 885, 532, 903]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 527, 89]]<|/det|> The signal is to be transmitted in digital form. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 920, 135]]<|/det|> The analogue signal is sampled at a frequency of \(1.0 \times 10^{3} \text{Hz}\) using an analogue-to-digital converter (ADC). The ADC produces 4-bit numbers. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 767, 166]]<|/det|> The times \(t\) at which the analogue signal is sampled are shown in Fig. 4.2. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 175, 865, 260]]<|/det|>
time
t/ms		01.02.03.04.05.06.0
digital
number		0010011001000101..............................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 241, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
Three uncharged capacitors of capacitances \(C_1\), \(C_2\) and \(C_3\) are connected in series with a battery of electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(E\) and a switch, as shown in Fig. 6.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 288, 725, 475]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 484, 532, 503]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 515, 920, 535]]<|/det|>
When the switch is closed, there is a charge \(+q\) on plate P of the capacitor of capacitance \(C_{1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 546, 890, 565]]<|/det|>
Show that the combined capacitance \(C\) of the three capacitors is given by the expression

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 571, 579, 604]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{1}{C} = \frac{1}{C_1} +\frac{1}{C_2} +\frac{1}{C_3}.\]

15μF.

A solenoid is connected in series with a battery and a switch, as illustrated in Fig. 8.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 412, 918, 432]]<|/det|>
As the current in the solenoid is switched on, there is a changing magnetic field inside the solenoid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 445, 144, 464]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 630, 183, 648]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 630, 336, 648]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 288, 920, 322]]<|/det|>
A constant current in the solenoid produces a uniform magnetic flux of flux density \(1.4 \text{mT}\) throughout the small coil.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
A bridge rectifier contains four diodes. The output of the rectifier is connected to a resistor R, as shown in Fig. 10.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 112, 779, 265]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 268, 537, 286]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 10.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 299, 819, 318]]<|/det|>
The variation with time \(t\) of the input e.m.f. \(E\) to the rectifier is given by the expression

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 330, 569, 349]]<|/det|>
\[E = 15\cos (210t)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 361, 504, 380]]<|/det|>
where \(t\) is measured in seconds and \(E\) in volts.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 392, 870, 411]]<|/det|>
The variation with time \(t\) of the potential difference \(V\) across resistor R is shown in Fig. 10.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[235, 419, 767, 567]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 580, 539, 598]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 10.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 611, 213, 628]]<|/det|>
Determine:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 642, 146, 660]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 641, 625, 660]]<|/det|>
the maximum potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{MAX}}\) across resistor R

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[524, 757, 920, 777]]<|/det|>
<form>V<sub>MAX</sub> = .......................................................V [1]

energy = ....................................................... eV <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 780, 181, 798]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 780, 920, 814]]<|/det|> Determine which metals will give rise to the emission of photoelectrons. Explain your answer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 826, 920, 845]]<|/det|> ............................................................................................................... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 857, 920, 875]]<|/det|> ............................................................................................................... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 857, 920, 875]]<|/det|> [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Photons of wavelength \(380 \text{nm}\) are incident normally on a metal surface at a rate of \(7.6 \times 10^{14} \text{s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 101, 804, 121]]<|/det|>
All the photons are absorbed in the surface and no photoelectrons are emitted.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 755, 152]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[520, 351, 920, 370]]<|/det|>
<form>force = .................................................... N [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 106, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 777, 91]]<|/det|> A sample of a radioactive isotope contains \(N\) nuclei of the isotope at time \(T\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 87, 920, 121]]<|/det|> At time \((T + \Delta T)\), the sample contains \((N - \Delta N)\) nuclei of the isotope. The time interval \(\Delta T\) is short. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 631, 152]]<|/det|> Use the symbols \(N, \Delta N, T\) and \(\Delta T\) to give expressions for: <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 180, 183]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 164, 631, 183]]<|/det|> the average activity of the sample during the time \(\Delta T\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 197, 920, 214]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 227, 181, 245]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 227, 616, 245]]<|/det|> the probability of decay of a nucleus in the time \(\Delta T\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 257, 920, 275]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 288, 180, 306]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 288, 490, 306]]<|/det|> the decay constant \(\lambda\) of the isotope. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 320, 920, 338]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 350, 146, 369]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 350, 860, 369]]<|/det|> The isotope polonium-208 ( \(^{208}_{84}\mathrm {Po})\) is radioactive and decays to form lead-204 ( \(^{204}_{82}\mathrm {Pb}\) ). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 368, 470, 387]]<|/det|> The nuclear equation for this decay is <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 396, 594, 421]]<|/det|> \[^{208}_{84}\mathrm {Po}\rightarrow ^{204}_{82}\mathrm {Pb}+_{2}^{4}\mathrm {He}.\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 432, 544, 450]]<|/det|> Data for nuclear masses are given in Fig. 12.1. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[336, 459, 662, 572]]<|/det|>
mass/u
\(^{4}_{2}\mathrm {He}\)4.002 603
\(^{204}_{82}\mathrm {Pb}\)203.973 043
\(^{208}_{84}\mathrm {Po}\)207.981 245

mass change = ....................................................... $u$ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 828, 920, 846]]<|/det|> [1]
